# The `AssignmentTrackingLowering` Class Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

<a href="/docs/api/classes/anonymous-namespace-assignmenttrackinganalysis-cpp-/assignmenttrackinglowering">AssignmentTrackingLowering</a> encapsulates a dataflow analysis over a function that interprets assignment tracking debug info metadata and stores in IR to create a map of variable locations. <a href="#details">More...</a>

## Description {#details}

<a href="/docs/api/classes/anonymous-namespace-assignmenttrackinganalysis-cpp-/assignmenttrackinglowering">AssignmentTrackingLowering</a> encapsulates a dataflow analysis over a function that interprets assignment tracking debug info metadata and stores in IR to create a map of variable locations.

Definition at line 990 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/assignmenttrackinganalysis-cpp">AssignmentTrackingAnalysis.cpp</a>.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/assignmenttrackinganalysis-cpp/#l01100">1100</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/assignmenttrackinganalysis-cpp">AssignmentTrackingAnalysis.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### AssignRecord {#a6e0b2146e9115e385d8e406b6c36e645}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>using anonymous&#95;namespace&#123;AssignmentTrackingAnalysis.cpp&#125;::AssignmentTrackingLowering::AssignRecord =  PointerUnion&lt;DbgAssignIntrinsic &#42;, DbgVariableRecord &#42;&gt;</>}>
An abstraction of the assignment of a value to a variable or memory location.

An <a href="/docs/api/structs/anonymous-namespace-assignmenttrackinganalysis-cpp-/assignmenttrackinglowering/assignment">Assignment</a> is Known or NoneOrPhi. A Known <a href="/docs/api/structs/anonymous-namespace-assignmenttrackinganalysis-cpp-/assignmenttrackinglowering/assignment">Assignment</a> means we have a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/diassignid">DIAssignID</a> ptr that represents it. NoneOrPhi means that we don&#39;t (or can&#39;t) know the <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/callingconv/#abdf8cf606905c10634e831390981b0ed">ID</a> of the last assignment that took place.

The <a href="/docs/api/structs/status">Status</a> of the <a href="/docs/api/structs/anonymous-namespace-assignmenttrackinganalysis-cpp-/assignmenttrackinglowering/assignment">Assignment</a> (Known or NoneOrPhi) is another join-semilattice. The partial order is: NoneOrPhi &gt; Known &#123;id&#95;0, id&#95;1, ...id&#95;N&#125;

i.e. for all values x and y where x != y: join(x, x) = x join(x, y) = NoneOrPhi

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/assignmenttrackinganalysis-cpp/#l01031">1031</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/assignmenttrackinganalysis-cpp">AssignmentTrackingAnalysis.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

## Enumerations

### enum class  {#a4012a71c02f4a13c5234aea48e772f4c}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>enum class anonymous_namespace&#123;AssignmentTrackingAnalysis.cpp&#125;::AssignmentTrackingLowering::LocKind </>}
 labels = {["strong"]}>
The kind of location in use for a variable, where Mem is the stack home, Val is an SSA value or const, and None means that there is not one single kind (either because there are multiple or because there is none; it may prove useful to split this into two values in the future).

<EnumerationList title="Enumeration values">

<Link id="a4012a71c02f4a13c5234aea48e772f4cadba5553473d129a7985fb532dc249ff4" />
<EnumerationListItem name="Mem">

</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="a4012a71c02f4a13c5234aea48e772f4ca5988c20a047cfe063999787584b0aca7" />
<EnumerationListItem name="Val">

</EnumerationListItem>

<Link id="a4012a71c02f4a13c5234aea48e772f4ca6adf97f83acf6453d4a6a4b1070f3754" />
<EnumerationListItem name="None">

</EnumerationListItem>

</EnumerationList>

<a href="#a4012a71c02f4a13c5234aea48e772f4c">LocKind</a> is a join-semilattice with the partial order: None &gt; Mem, Val

i.e. join(Mem, Mem) = Mem join(Val, Val) = Val join(Mem, Val) = None join(None, Mem) = None join(None, Val) = None join(None, None) = None

Note: the order is not <code>None &gt; Val &gt; Mem</code> because we&#39;re using <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/diassignid">DIAssignID</a> to name assignments and are not tracking the actual stored values. Therefore currently there&#39;s no way to ensure that Mem values and Val values are the same. This could be a future extension, though it&#39;s not clear that many additional locations would be recovered that way in practice as the likelihood of this sitation arising naturally seems incredibly low.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/assignmenttrackinganalysis-cpp/#l01015">1015</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/assignmenttrackinganalysis-cpp">AssignmentTrackingAnalysis.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

</SectionDefinition>

<SectionDefinition>

## joinMethods


Functions that implement <code>join</code> (the least upper bound) for the join-semilattice types used in the dataflow.

There is an explicit bottom value (⊥) for some types and and explicit top value (⊤) for all types. By definition: <CodeBlock>Join(A, B) &gt;= A &amp;&amp; Join(A, B) &gt;= B
Join(A, ⊥) = A
Join(A, ⊤) = ⊤
</CodeBlock>

These invariants are important for monotonicity.

For the map-type functions, all unmapped keys in an empty map are associated with a bottom value (⊥). This represents their values being unknown. Unmapped keys in non-empty maps (joining two maps with a key only present in one) represents either a variable going out of scope or dropped debug info. It is assumed the key is associated with a top value (⊤) in this case (unknown location / assignment).
